message: What do you guys think about this?
http://techcrunch.com/2011/02/12/search-still-sucks/

I like the point about how niche platforms are much better at particular things. Maybe at some point we will have enough of these built that someone will build a kind of meta layer on top of them. One for programming questions, one for travel, one for clothes, one for a new computer, etc...
@ericflo I get what Arrington is going for, but it's short-sighted. Plenty of people are working on improving search. Technologies just aren't there yet but will be.
someday every person will have that kind of power in a laptop
First example that came to my mind was IBM's Watson
Search is just so hard to get right.  I'd be surprised if someone were able to beat Google in the near term.

@timcash The problem with that is that practically any niche can be continually specialized down to really fine points. Then if you had a meta layer covering a lot of really small points of contact with specialized information, you'd essentially have...Google. For that reason, I don't quite get how lots of niche platforms solves search problems better than a smart general search like Google. I think the next steps are going to have to come from improvement in new areas, from social recommendations to natural language processing
whoo nlp
It feels to me that currently, the main problem isn't finding better results as much as eliminating the bad ones. The amount of link farms in some kinds of searches are staggering.
search doesn't suck, search IS pretty good
for example, so I can announce that I'm content starbucks is almost open
I've been Googling for 10 years straight, it would take something pretty big
@ericflo what are your thoughts on a lobby?
The article title should be "Search still sucks ~more~ than it should"
define "your info"?
damn, we need a like button (of sorts). RE: equilibrium - I agree
it's also very hard to link to the page of the betty crocker book which has your answer
search is at an equilibrium vs. what you pay for it - which is nothing.
thanks :-)
thing is, I can't imagine anything that would ever make me switch search engine
I've got this related theory that often, your info is just not out there in the free web. Even 18 years after it started. what do you think?

anything you might be interested in. Example: "what's the best blender". This might be written in just the betty crocker magazine, which is not free. You search in google for it, and of course you only get crap - the answer is just not on the web.
My point is that people overrate the value of the free web. There are many cases where you won't find your info on the free web. People expect stuff that is just plain not there.
